Award.AwardTitle: New Redox Tags For Bioorganometallic Chemistry and Electrode Modification
Award.AbstractNarration:
With support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging (CMI) Program the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms (CSDM) Program in the Division of Chemistry, Professor William Geiger and his group at the University of Vermont are seeking to identify new directions in the application of organometallic redox tags to medical imaging and to surface science. It takes advantage of the one-electron oxidation of strongly IR-active "piano-stool" tags bonded to molecular substrates or to conducting surfaces through their cyclopentadienyl (Cp) or cyclobutadiene (Cb) rings. Before or after tagging, one or more carbonyl ligands can be substituted by donor ligands using "redox switching" to manipulate both the chemical and physical effects of the tag, including E1/2 potential, IR frequency, lipophilicity, and topology. A key goal is to provide to the chemical and biological communities a molecularly broadened toolbox of organometallic redox tags having a dramatic IR spectroscopic signature, allowing redox and IR imaging even at the cellular level. Anodic oxidative studies will be carried out for compounds in which MCp(CO)3 (M = Mn, Re) groups are tagged to tamoxifen as a model to allow, for the first time, imaging of both the location and redox state of organometallic tags in biological systems. Covalent attachment of piano-stools to electrodes will also be carried out for the purpose of providing entry to a molecularly diverse set of strongly IR-active organometallic monolayers. Piano-stool compounds anchored via cycloadditon click attachment to carbon will be characterized using advanced surface analysis methods in collaboration with the Energy Materials Center at Cornell University. Unprecedented studies of CO-substitution rates, ion-pairing effects, and monomer/dimer equilibria in organometallic monolayers will be carried out, increasing our understanding of the reactivities of surface-bound organometallics. Success in the proposed research could lead to the basis of a new approach to cell imaging, one in which the redox state of a molecular tag can be followed as a function of time and place. The proposed innovative organometallic electro-grafting methods will broaden the molecular possibilities for chemically-modified conducting surfaces, and the ways in which they may be applied to needs in catalysis, corrosion, composite materials, sensors, and energy.

Strong collaborations with ENS Paris and with Prof. Jannie Swarts and other students and faculty at the University of the Free State in South Africa will provide an aspect of international outreach to the program. Expansion of the pool of underrepresented groups will be addressed through Project SEED internships at the University of Vermont (UVM) and by inclusion of African-American or Hispanic summer research interns at UVM recruited from either Chicago State University or the University of New Mexico.

Institution.Name: University of Vermont & State Agricultural College
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF VERMONT & STATE AGRICULTURAL COLLEGE

Performance_Institution.Name: University of Vermont & State Agricultural College

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
A new way of giving a “chemical face” to the surface of a carbon electrode has been discovered. This advance in applied electrochemistry could be applied to the design of biological sensors and to devices that store or deliver energy (batteries, fuel cells) while using only readily abundant and sustainable materials. Carbon electrodes are known for their simplicity, low environmental impact, and ease with which they allow electrons to be transferred. However, carbon lacks a good “chemical sense” and is seldom able to recognize differences in the structures of target molecules which approach its surface, thereby limiting its ability to either act as a chemical sensor or transfer electrons to selected target molecules. This limitation was overcome by using an “ethynyl” (C ≡ C) group as a linkage between the carbon surface and chemical molecules (CM) that can be designed to interact with specific target molecules (T). The ethynyl group bonds very strongly to the carbon surface and is efficient at passing electrons back and forth between the electrode, the CM molecule, and the target molecule. The method provides a new, broadly applicable, approach to the design of “chemically smart” carbon electrodes.

 

     Electrodes are key components in the function of sensors that are being employed in a number of important applications in environmental and national security (chemical sensors) as well as medicine (biochemical sensors). The new method can be employed for the production of sensors that go beyond those currently available and are made from carbon, a cheap and readily available element. 

     The key discovery of this grant period was an off-shoot from the work that was originally proposed, and could only have arisen because of the experimental and intellectual flexibility that is inherent to an NSF grant. The grant resulted in a meaningful breakthrough in applied electrochemistry. It also had a significant impact on scientific education, owing to its support of the research experience of high school summer apprentices and undergraduate and graduate students at the University of Vermont. It also supported the professional development of two postdoctoral associates who now hold teaching positions in chemistry at a college and junior college.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 10/30/2017
Modified by: William E Geiger
